q: 1st vice president anne-marie johnson pointed out to back stage that the post cards constitute an informal poll and not an official election. "obviously, this is not what we do on elections," she said. but when we do polling- email polling, phone polling- this is exactly what we've done, where we know who the member is and what division they live in and/or work from.... we've done this a million times. this is nothing new. johnson said that although senior staffers have had access to records of how individual members voted in polls, the information is used only for the statistical analysis Doug Allen described. she questioned why Doug Allen or other staffers would want

"we know many elected officials still consider anything dealing with guns to be controversial, but yesterday's elections should encourage them to start moving forward," Paul Helmke said. we know we still have to work hard to get common sense gun laws adopted. but gun violence victims and the survivors of loved ones lost to gun violence should be hopeful that we can make some real progress to protect our families and communities from gun violence in the next few years. as the nation's largest, non-partisan, grassroots organization leading the fight to prevent gun violence, the Sarah Brady campaign, with its dedicated network of million mom march chapters, works to enact and enforce sensible gun laws
